item.title: Trump Signs Pandemic Relief Bill After Unemployment Aid Lapses
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump, who had stalled on the bill for days, issued a series of demands for congressional action even as he signed it, though lawmakers showed little immediate enthusiasm for his requests.
item.description: After calling the measure a “disgrace,” President Trump unexpectedly signed the bill, extending expanded unemployment benefits and an eviction moratorium, and keeping the government open.
item.dc:creator: Emily Cochrane, Nelson D. Schwartz and Gillian Friedman

item.title: Stimulus Deal Q&A: Second Check, Unemployment Insurance and More
item.description: Lawmakers agreed to issue stimulus payments of $600 and distribute a federal unemployment benefit of $300 for at least 10 weeks. But that money will take time to start arriving.
item.category: Coronavirus Aid, Relief, and Economic Security Act (2020)
item.dc:creator: Tara Siegel Bernard and Ron Lieber

item.title: A Quiet Life, a Thunderous Death, and a Nightmare That Shook Nashville
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers investigate the house that had belonged to Anthony Quinn Warner, the 63-year-old man who apparently blew himself up in the Christmas morning explosion in Nashville.
item.description: DNA tests show that Anthony Warner blew himself up along with a chunk of downtown Nashville on Christmas morning.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas, Adam Goldman and Jamie McGee

item.title: Who Should Get the Covid-19 Vaccine Next? A Debate
item.description: With limited doses available, and a pandemic claiming more lives every day, a complex moral calculus has begun. Five thinkers weigh the choices ahead.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: Emily Bazelon

item.title: 450 Million People, 27 Nations: Europe’s Vaccination Campaign Takes Off
item.description: The European Union’s vaccinations started with older people and the workers who care for them. Catch up on the latest Covid-19 developments.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Did These New York Clinics Ignore Rules on Who Gets Vaccinated First?
item.media:description: Many of ParCare’s patients are Orthodox Jews, a population that has been hard-hit by the virus, and the clinics have worked with the city on contact-tracing efforts.
item.description: The state is investigating whether a network of urgent care clinics provided vaccinations to members of the public who were not yet entitled to have the shots.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik

item.title: How Heather Cox Richardson Became a Breakout Star on Substack
item.media:credit: Tristan Spinski for The New York Times
item.media:description: Heather Cox Richardson, a history professor at Boston College, is more or less by accident the most successful independent journalist in America.
item.description: She is the breakout star of the newsletter platform Substack, doing the opposite of most media as she calmly situates the news of the day in the long sweep of American history.
item.dc:creator: Ben Smith

item.title: ‘Sign o’ the Times’: How Prince Wrote and Recorded a Classic Song
item.description: In the latest Diary of a Song, Prince’s estate and his closest collaborators offer an unprecedented peek into his creative process.
item.dc:creator: Joe Coscarelli, Alicia DeSantis, Antonio de Luca, Ruru Kuo, Kaisha Murzamadiyeva, Kevin Oliver and Shane O’Neill

item.title: How Two British Orthodontists Became Celebrities to Incels
item.media:credit: Levon Biss for The New York Times
item.description: The Mews, a father-son team of orthodontists, have an unusual theory about the source of crooked teeth — one that has earned them a following in some of the darker corners of the internet.
item.dc:creator: William Brennan

item.title: Reginald Foster, Vatican Latinist Who Tweeted in the Language, Dies at 81
item.description: One of the world’s foremost experts on Latin, Father Foster was a monk who looked like a stevedore, dressed like a janitor and swore like a sailor.
item.dc:creator: Margalit Fox

item.title: The Sunday Read: ‘Cher Everlasting’
item.media:credit: Christopher Anderson/Magnum, for The New York Times
item.media:description: Cher, transformed in “Moonstruck.”
item.description: “Moonstruck” sustained many people through the pandemic. Caity Weaver spoke with Cher about why the film endures.

item.title: Special Delivery: Thousands of Books
item.description: Special Delivery: Thousands of Books
item.category: New York Times Neediest Cases Fund
item.dc:creator: Charley Locke

item.title: ‘The 46th’: Will Georgia’s Races Change the Senate?
item.description: Jamelle Bouie joins Michelle and Ross to predict the results of the runoff elections.

item.title: The Haunting of Tulsa, Okla.
item.media:credit: Joseph Rushmore for The New York Times
item.media:description: A section of a Tulsa, Okla., cemetery is roped off where a mass grave has been discovered.
item.description: A recently unearthed mass grave may soon provide answers about what happened to victims of the 1921 Tulsa Race Massacre.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: Brent Staples

item.title: ‘I Want to Be at the Table When the Next Donald Trump Shows Up’
item.description: What’s your resolution for the next four years?
item.dc:creator: Nayeema Raza

item.title: Can Joe Biden Make American Politics Decent Again?
item.description: The new year will prove whether we have any decency left in us.
item.dc:creator: Frank Bruni

item.title: The Runner Sara Hall's 2020 Breakthrough
item.media:description: Sara Hall finishing second in the 2020 London Marathon.
item.description: Sara Hall is a 37-year-old elite marathoner and mother of four. She showed me how years of setbacks can lead to unexpected rewards.
item.dc:creator: Lindsay Crouse

item.title: Travel After the Coronavirus Pandemic Might Be Different
item.description: The future of travel will involve fewer selfies from Icelandic spas.
item.dc:creator: Tariro Mzezewa

item.title: Are You Sure You Want to Go Back to the Office?
item.description: The future of work is flexibility.
item.dc:creator: Anne Helen Petersen

item.title: Covid-19 Taught Me to Value My Friends
item.description: It’s been a year of loneliness and isolation. In 2021, we’ll celebrate.
item.dc:creator: Maeve Higgins

item.title: Cities Will Survive Covid-19
item.description: Because neither the United States nor the world can do without cities.
item.dc:creator: Farhad Manjoo

item.title: Ancient DNA Is Changing How We Think About the Caribbean
item.media:credit: Kayana Szymczak for The New York Times
item.media:description: Scientists now have data concerning the entire genomes of more than 260 people of the ancient Caribbean.
item.description: New research delivers surprising findings about Indigenous people in the region before contact with Europeans.
item.dc:creator: David Reich and Orlando Patterson

item.title: The Coronavirus Brought Out Nasty Puritanism About Sex
item.description: The pandemic has brought out a nasty puritanism.
item.dc:creator: Megan Nolan

item.title: Covid-19 Changed Our Restaurant's Business Overnight
item.description: In a world where everything was changing, the menu at a small New Orleans restaurant also had to adapt. Not everyone seemed to get that.
item.dc:creator: Richard Horner

item.title: Can Jeff Koons Teach Me to Paint?
item.media:description: Jeff Koons with his “Gazing Ball (Birdbath).” He is sharing his secrets with student-artists as an instructor for MasterClass.
item.description: Jeff Koons has entered the classroom at 65, signing on as an instructor for MasterClass. An art critic tuned in to glean some of the master’s magic.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Russeth

item.title: I Think Beethoven Encoded His Deafness in His Music
item.media:description: “Is it an exaggeration to say that composers after Beethoven, the vast majority of them hearing, were forever changed by a deaf aesthetic?”
item.description: Gabriela Lena Frank, a composer born with high-moderate/near-profound hearing loss, describes her creative experience.
item.dc:creator: Gabriela Lena Frank

item.title: Video Shows Keyon Harrold's Son Falsely Accused of Theft in SoHo Hotel
item.media:description: In an image from the video taken by Keyon Harrold, a woman accuses his son of stealing her phone.
item.description: A woman falsely accused the teenager of taking her phone in the video, which fueled concerns about racial profiling. It was shared by the teenager’s father, a prominent jazz musician.
item.dc:creator: Mihir Zaveri

item.title: Army Green Beret Charged in Fatal Shooting at Illinois Bowling Alley
item.media:credit: Scott P. Yates/Rockford Register Star, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Law enforcement officers at the scene of the shooting at Don Carter Lanes on Saturday in Rockford, Ill.
item.description: Three people were killed and three others injured in what the police described as a “completely random” act.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
United States Army Special Forces (Green Berets)
item.dc:creator: Christina Morales and Bryan Pietsch

item.title: More Than 190,000 Ceiling Fans Are Recalled After Blades Detach
item.media:description: There have been 47 reports of blades detaching from models of the fans that were recalled. A distributor said the issue was an “isolated manufacturing defect.”
item.description: The flying blades can cause injury and damage property, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said.
item.dc:creator: Bryan Pietsch

item.title: NFL Week 16: What We Learned
item.media:description: Diontae Johnson began the Steelers’ comeback against the Colts with a diving catch for a 39-yard touchdown. Ben Roethlisberger added two more scoring passes in the fourth quarter to help Pittsburgh secure a 28-24 win.
item.description: The Steelers came back to beat the Colts, Kansas City survived against Atlanta and Jacksonville secured the No. 1 pick in the draft.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Hoffman

item.title: Jon Huber, Who Rose to Fame With World Wrestling Entertainment, Dies at 41
item.media:description: Jon Huber, who was also known as Luke Harper, was known for his soft-spoken intensity in the ring.
item.description: Mr. Huber, who was known in the ring as Brodie Lee and Luke Harper, died from a “lung issue” unrelated to Covid-19, his wife said.
item.dc:creator: Marie Fazio

item.title: In a Village of Widows, the Opium Trade Has Taken a Deadly Toll
item.media:credit: Jim Huylebroek for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women in Qala-e-Biwaha, or the “village of widows.” They survive on earnings from the wool-processing trade, or donations from relatives and aid groups.
item.description: Afghan men in an impoverished border settlement die trying to smuggle opium into Iran, leaving behind loved ones forced to survive on their own.
item.dc:creator: David Zucchino and Najim Rahim

item.title: Managing Movie Superheroes Is About to Get a Lot More Complicated
item.media:credit: Elizabeth Weinberg for The New York Times
item.media:description: DC Films, led by Walter Hamada, plans to release movies featuring DC Comics heroes like Wonder Woman, Superman and Batman at a much faster pace.
item.description: Walter Hamada, who runs DC Films, is overseeing a dizzying number of projects, part of a swarm of comics-based stories coming from Hollywood.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes

item.title: Battered Turkish Economy Puts a Powerful Erdogan to the Test
item.media:description: A ferry passing through Istanbul. Nine months into the pandemic, there are signs that a significant portion of the population is overwhelmed by debt and increasingly going hungry.
item.description: Turkey’s veteran leader played an aggressive hand abroad, but as the country’s economy plummets, he is feeling ire at home as many Turks struggle to buy food.
item.dc:creator: Carlotta Gall

item.title: Phil Niekro, Hall of Fame Knuckleball Pitcher, Dies at 81
item.media:description: Phil Niekro in 1987, pitching for the Yankees at age 45. He was known for his knuckleball, and had a career record of 318-274.
item.description: A five-time all-star, he played in the major leagues for 24 seasons, but never made it to the World Series.
item.dc:creator: Richard Goldstein

item.title: David Attenborough Still Has Hope for Our Future
item.media:description: Sir David Attenborough’s new nature documentary for Discovery+ is intended to be “an antidote to climate change gloom,” he said.
item.description: At 94, the beloved British naturalist remains curious and optimistic. He talked about his new docu-series, “A Perfect Planet,” and why the coronavirus may prove to have some positive consequences.
item.dc:creator: Etan Smallman

item.title: How Will We Eat in 2021? 11 Predictions to Chew On
item.description: Meal kits from your favorite restaurant, snacks that help you sleep and other ways the food world may respond in a year of big changes.
item.dc:creator: Kim Severson

item.title: A New Pinocchio Film Returns to the Tale’s Dark Origins
item.media:description: From left, Roberto Benigni, who plays Geppetto, and the director Matteo Garrone, on the set of “Pinocchio.”
item.description: The Italian director Matteo Garrone hopes to surprise audiences this Christmas with a very literal retelling of the children’s classic.
item.dc:creator: Elisabetta Povoledo

item.title: The Doodles of Great Writers
item.description: Nabokov left a butterfly, Roxane Gay drew an elephant and Isabel Allende offered a caricature of herself — a few gems hidden in the guest book of the 92nd Street Y’s Unterberg Poetry Center.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Schwartz

item.title: Dancing by Herself: When the Waltz Went Solo
item.media:credit: Rudolf Jobst/Österreichisches Theatermuseum, via Imagno and Getty Images
item.media:description: Waltz with me: Grete Wiesenthal, in Vienna, around 1908.
item.description: Grete Wiesenthal, a ballet-trained Viennese dancer, made the waltz modern and a vehicle for solo expression.
item.dc:creator: Meryl Cates

item.title: Carey Mulligan Won’t Let Hollywood Off the Hook
item.media:credit: Danny Kasirye for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mulligan said of one review that focused on her looks: “I was like, ‘Really? For this film, you’re going to write something that is so transparent? Now? In 2020?’”
item.description: The actress delivered the performance of her career in the dark comedy “Promising Young Woman.” Then came those with their tired views of women.
item.dc:creator: Kyle Buchanan

item.title: The Tiny Victories That Got Parents Through 2020
item.description: It’s been a rough year. Let’s celebrate the little wins.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: The Best Movies on Amazon Prime Video Right Now
item.media:description: Dustin Hoffman in “Little Big Man” (1970), about a survivor of the Battle of the Little Bighorn.
item.description: New films, and classics, just keep coming, but you don’t have to drill down to find the finest selections to stream. We’ll do the heavy lifting. You press play.
item.dc:creator: Jason Bailey

item.title: How We Reported on Pollution in New Delhi Through Two Children
item.media:credit: Omar Adam Khan and Karan Deep Singh for The New York Times
item.media:description: Monu, 13, left, and Aamya, 11, have never met, but they and their families agreed to participate in the project, letting reporters into their lives for almost 16 hours.
item.description: The idea was simple: compare the difference in exposure to unclean air among wealthy and poor families by tracking two kids for a day. Pulling it off was trickier.
item.dc:creator: Derek Watkins

item.title: How Early Covid Vaccine Doubters Now Show a Willingness to Roll Up Their Sleeves
item.media:credit: Sarah Blesener for The New York Times
item.media:description: For months, Tina Kleinfeldt, a surgical recovery nurse at Long Island Jewish Medical Center, did not want the coronavirus vaccine. But she changed her mind and became the first on her unit to get it.
item.description: Polls show that pervasive skepticism is melting, partly because of the high efficacy rates in trials and the images of real people getting the shot.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman

item.title: A New Population of Blue Whales Was Discovered Hiding in the Indian Ocean
item.media:description: Researchers said that the blue whale song that crackled through the team’s underwater recordings was unlike any they had heard.
item.description: The whales in the group seem to sing a unique song.
item.dc:creator: Katherine J. Wu

item.title: More Mammals Are Hiding Their Secret Glow
item.media:description: Stuffed bare-nosed wombats fluoresce under a black light at the Western Australia Museum.
item.description: First it was platypuses. Now we may be dealing with glowing Tasmanian devils, echidnas and wombats.
item.dc:creator: Cara Giaimo

item.title: Fruit Flies Are Essential to Science. So Are the Workers Who Keep Them Alive.
item.media:credit: Kaiti Sullivan for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Flipped” vials that had contained fruit flies in the Bloomington Drosophila Stock Center at Indiana University.
item.description: Sustaining the world’s biggest Drosophila collection during the pandemic has been a challenge, but the people in Indiana who supply the insects to labs around the world stay dedicated to the task.
item.dc:creator: Cara Giaimo

item.title: Turn Your Sex Life Around
item.description: With all its stress and uncertainty, this year hasn’t exactly been a banner year for intimacy. But that can change.
item.dc:creator: Meaghan O’Connell

item.title: Trump’s Team Eyes the Exits
item.description: Farewell, henchmen.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Cottle

item.title: Homes That Sold for Around $450,000
item.description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
item.dc:creator: C. J. Hughes

item.title: Spelling Bee
item.description: Use 7 letters to make as many words as you can.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: The Crossword, Tiles and More
item.description: Solve the daily puzzle edited by Will Shortz, or try out other games like the Mini and Vertex.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Vertex
item.description: Connect the dots to reveal the hidden picture.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Trump Signs COVID-19 Relief Deal After His Criticism Threatened To Derail It
item.description: President Trump's signature, even after bashing the legislation, puts an end to uncertainty over when millions of Americans will receive the economic relief provided in the massive bill.
item.content:encoded:
President Trump's signature, even after bashing the legislation, puts an end to uncertainty over when millions of Americans will receive the economic relief provided in the massive bill.

(Image credit: Al Drago/Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Swasey

item.title: What's On The Menu In Ancient Pompeii? Duck, Goat, Snail, Researchers Say
item.description: For the first time, a food stall has been excavated in its entirety in the city. The stall had remnants of 2,000-year-old food — giving researchers a glimpse into Pompeii street food.
item.content:encoded:
For the first time, a food stall has been excavated in its entirety in the city. The stall had remnants of 2,000-year-old food — giving researchers a glimpse into Pompeii street food.

(Image credit: Luigi Spina/Archaeological Park of Pompeii via AP)
item.dc:creator: Reese Oxner

item.title: Why The World Is Seeing Some Of Its Most Extreme Pandemic Lockdowns
item.description: Even as the European Union began vaccine rollouts on Sunday, nations around the globe are instituting severe lockdowns and travel restrictions. Fear of the U.K. variant is a key reason.
item.content:encoded:
Even as the European Union began vaccine rollouts on Sunday, nations around the globe are instituting severe lockdowns and travel restrictions. Fear of the U.K. variant is a key reason.

(Image credit: Romeo Gacad/AFP via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Jason Beaubien

item.title: Hall Of Famer Phil Niekro, Known For His Knuckleball, Dies At 81
item.description: "Knucksie," as he was known, pitched the most games of any Braves pitcher. He retired at 48 years old in 1987.
item.content:encoded:
"Knucksie," as he was known, pitched the most games of any Braves pitcher. He retired at 48 years old in 1987.

(Image credit: Associated Press)
item.dc:creator: Matthew S. Schwartz

item.title: Nashville Blast Suspect Died In Explosion, Officials Say
item.description: Authorities revealed that DNA testing shows the man believed to be the perpetrator of the Christmas Day incident died in the blast.
item.content:encoded:
Authorities revealed that DNA testing shows the man believed to be the perpetrator of the Christmas Day incident died in the blast.

(Image credit: Mark Humphrey/AP)
item.dc:creator: Matthew S. Schwartz

item.title: COVID Love Story: Can A Malawian Bachelor And A Dutch Bachelorette Make It?
item.description: They met and fell in love while working for a nonprofit in his country. He came to visit her in the Netherlands. Because of the pandemic, his hometown visited lasted 7 months. Would love conquer all?
item.content:encoded:
They met and fell in love while working for a nonprofit in his country. He came to visit her in the Netherlands. Because of the pandemic, his hometown visited lasted 7 months. Would love conquer all?

(Image credit: Julia Gunther for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Nick Schonfeld

item.title: EU Begins Its Vaccine Rollout With Goal Of Inoculating 450 Million Against COVID-19
item.description: Leaders from across the European Union's 27 member-states celebrated the start of vaccination efforts on Sunday. EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen called it "a European success story."
item.content:encoded:
Leaders from across the European Union's 27 member-states celebrated the start of vaccination efforts on Sunday. EU Commission President Ursula von der Leyen called it "a European success story."

(Image credit: NurPhoto/NurPhoto via Getty Images)
item.dc:creator: Joanna Kakissis

item.title: Coronavirus World Map: Tracking The Spread Of The Outbreak
item.description: A map of confirmed COVID-19 cases and deaths around the world. The respiratory disease has spread rapidly across six continents and has killed at least 1 million globally.
item.content:encoded:
A map of confirmed COVID-19 cases and deaths around the world. The respiratory disease has spread rapidly across six continents and has killed at least 1 million globally.

(Image credit: Ruth Talbot/NPR)
item.dc:creator: Daniel Wood

item.title: Coronavirus Is Surging: How Severe Is Your State's Outbreak?
item.description: View NPR's maps and graphics to see where COVID-19 is hitting hardest in the U.S., which state outbreaks are growing and which are leveling off.
item.content:encoded:
View NPR's maps and graphics to see where COVID-19 is hitting hardest in the U.S., which state outbreaks are growing and which are leveling off.

(Image credit: NPR)
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Adeline

item.title: Do-It-Yourself Contact Tracing Is A 'Last Resort' In Communities Besieged By COVID-19
item.description: The coronavirus is spreading so fast that cases are outpacing the contact-tracing capacities of some local health departments. Some have asked people who test positive to do their own contact tracing.
item.content:encoded:
The coronavirus is spreading so fast that cases are outpacing the contact-tracing capacities of some local health departments. Some have asked people who test positive to do their own contact tracing.

(Image credit: David Goldman/AP)
item.dc:creator: Brett Dahlberg

item.title: Military Member Charged In Shooting At Illinois Bowling Alley That Left 3 Dead
item.description: Police say the incident appears to be "completely random" and are investigating. Two of those wounded were teenagers, one of whom was shot in the face.
item.content:encoded:
Police say the incident appears to be "completely random" and are investigating. Two of those wounded were teenagers, one of whom was shot in the face.

(Image credit: Winnebago County Sheriff's Office via AP)
item.dc:creator: Reese Oxner

item.title: Jobless Benefits Lapse For Millions As Trump Withholds Signature On Relief Bill
item.description: The nearly $900 billion package includes an extension of jobless aid. The president's criticisms of the bill, including that relief payments would be too small, caught much of Washington by surprise.
item.content:encoded:
The nearly $900 billion package includes an extension of jobless aid. The president's criticisms of the bill, including that relief payments would be too small, caught much of Washington by surprise.

(Image credit: Patrick Semansky/AP)
item.dc:creator: Jason Slotkin

item.title: From Polio To The COVID Vaccine, Dr. Peter Salk Sees Great Progress
item.description: At age 9, Dr. Salk was one of the first to get the polio vaccine in the 1950s that was invented by his father. Salk, now 76, says he's hugely impressed by the rapid development of the COVID vaccine.
item.content:encoded:
At age 9, Dr. Salk was one of the first to get the polio vaccine in the 1950s that was invented by his father. Salk, now 76, says he's hugely impressed by the rapid development of the COVID vaccine.

(Image credit: AP)
item.dc:creator: Greg Myre

item.title: Authorities Search For Nashville Bomber As Governor Asks For Emergency Declaration
item.description: A day after the early Christmas explosion injured three people and damaged dozens of buildings in downtown Nashville, Tenn., large swaths of the state's communications networks were still down.
item.content:encoded:
A day after the early Christmas explosion injured three people and damaged dozens of buildings in downtown Nashville, Tenn., large swaths of the state's communications networks were still down.

(Image credit: Mark Humphrey/AP)
item.dc:creator: Matthew S. Schwartz

item.title: Barry Lopez, Acclaimed Author And Traveler Beyond Many Horizons, Dies At 75
item.description: Lopez — who won a National Book Award in 1986 for Arctic Dreams — wrote about his travels to far places. But his writings aren't just travelogues, they remind us of how precious life on Earth is.
item.content:encoded:
Lopez — who won a National Book Award in 1986 for Arctic Dreams — wrote about his travels to far places. But his writings aren't just travelogues, they remind us of how precious life on Earth is.

(Image credit: John W. Clark)
item.dc:creator: Dave Blanchard

item.title: Covid: Trump signs relief and spending package into law
item.description: The measure restores unemployment benefits and averts a partial US government shutdown.?

item.title: Nashville explosion: Camper van blast suspect named by police
item.description: Investigators say Anthony Quinn Warner, 63, died in the powerful explosion on Christmas Day.

item.title: Boy Scouts of America accuse Girl Scouts of starting 'war'
item.description: The two organisations are caught in a legal battle after the Boy Scouts started recruiting girls.

item.title: Brodie Lee: AEW and ex-WWE Wrestler Jon Huber dies age 41
item.description: The wrestling world pays tribute to Jon Huber, who was known to fans as Brodie Lee or Luke Harper.

item.title: Coronavirus: Cases of new variant appear worldwide
item.description: Several European nations as well as Canada and Japan detect the variant first reported in the UK.

item.title: Chinese economy to overtake US 'by 2028' due to Covid
item.description: A UK-based think tank says the pandemic has caused economic momentum to shift further in favour of Asia.

item.title: 737 Max: Air Canada flight in unscheduled landing after engine issue
item.description: The plane with three crew landed safely after rerouting on a flight from the US to Canada.

item.title: Gingerbread monolith appears in San Francisco's Corona Heights
item.description: The tall, baked structure appeared in Corona Heights Park on Christmas Day, delighting locals.

item.title: Black US doctor dies of Covid alleging racist hospital care
item.description: The 52-year-old doctor wrote in a post from her hospital bed that she had to "beg" for treatment.

item.title: Michael Jackson: Neverland Ranch 'sold to billionaire for $22m'
item.description: Billionaire Ron Burkle reportedly buys the estate for a quarter of its initial asking price.

item.title: How delivery drivers became vital in the pandemic
item.description: They made sure no-one had to leave the house but now they are taking on an even more important role.

item.title: Trump pardons Paul Manafort, Roger Stone and Charles Kushner
item.description: Two key allies jailed over the Russia inquiry benefit from the latest wave of presidential pardons.

item.title: US election 2020: FBI links Iran to websites targeting poll officials
item.description: The websites contained death threats and contact details of 38 US officials and election workers.

item.title: Inauguration 2021: What happens on the day Biden is sworn in?
item.description: On 20 January, Joe Biden will officially become president. Here's what you need to know.

item.title: US presidents' pets: Biden dogs Major and Champ to restore White House tradition
item.description: From Socks the cat to Macaroni the pony, the US presidential tradition is returning with Joe Biden.

item.title: Biden cabinet: Does this new team better reflect America?
item.description: The role of a president's inaugural cabinet goes beyond just policy - let's take a closer look.

item.title: US election 2020: Why Republicans are fighting in Georgia
item.description: Sparks fly as the traditionally Republican state that chose Joe Biden might also hand him the Senate.

item.title: US election 2020: What legal challenges remain for Trump?
item.description: The president says the result was "stolen" but his lawyers have so far had little success in court.

item.title: Alfred Bourgeois: Second death row inmate executed in two days
item.description: President Donald Trump has planned three more executions before he leaves office on 20 January.

item.title: In Trump’s final days, a rush of federal executions
item.description: The executions put Mr Trump on track to be the most prolific execution president in modern history.

item.title: Where does the Republican Party go after Trump?
item.description: What places like Ohio reveal about President Donald Trump's legacy on the Republican Party.

item.title: 'Brother against brother' in Trump country
item.description: What's it like to be a Biden voter in a Trump heartland where many believe the election was rigged?

item.title: Can Georgia's teenagers change Biden’s presidency?
item.description: Newly eligible voters could have a big impact on who controls the Senate and define the nature of Joe Biden's presidency.

item.title: Trump presidency's final days: 'In his mind, he will not have lost'
item.description: An eerie quiet has descended on the White House as attempts to challenge the election result founder.

item.title: What Biden's new foreign policy team tells us
item.description: US foreign policy experts weigh in on what the new slate of top diplomats means for global affairs.

item.title: Biden announces all-female senior press team
item.description: Joe Biden has pledged to shape one of the most diverse US presidential cabinets ever.

item.title: Covid in the classroom: How the pandemic changed these three teachers' lives
item.description: Three teachers in the US reflect on how drastically their jobs have changed during 2020.

item.title: Paul Whelan: Grim life of US 'spy' in Russian labour camp
item.description: Paul Whelan was convicted as an American spy earlier this year and sentenced to 16 years in prison.

item.title: The President signed the legislation after a lengthy delay, extending unemployment assistance to millions and averting a government shutdown
item.description: On Christmas Eve, staff at Mar-a-Lago made preparations for President Donald Trump to sign the Covid-19 relief package and government funding bill, a holiday gift of relief to millions of Americans suffering in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: When will you get a second stimulus check?
item.description: Editor's note: This story originally ran December 18, 2020. It has been updated with President Donald Trump signing relief legislation that includes stimulus checks.

item.title: Here's what's in the second stimulus package
item.description: President Donald Trump signed on Sunday evening a $900 billion pandemic relief bill into law that includes enhanced unemployment benefits and direct cash payments.

item.title: 'Shouldn't be big news': Bash on Trump signing Covid bill
item.description: After letting critical benefits lapse for millions of jobless Americans and poising the government for a partial shutdown, President Donald Trump signed the $2.3 trillion dollar coronavirus relief and government funding bill passed by Congress.

item.title: GOP lawmaker on what was happening behind the scenes after Trump delayed bill
item.description: CNN's Dana Bash talks to Rep. Tom Reed (R-NY) and Rep. Josh Gottheimer (D-NJ), co-chairs of the bipartisan Problem Solvers Caucus, about President Donald Trump signing the coronavirus relief bill after days of delay.

item.title: Analysis: Why Trump is already the 2024 GOP frontrunner
item.description: Poll of the week: A new Gallup poll finds that 87% of self-identified Republican voters approve of President Donald Trump's job performance.

item.title: Police name Nashville bomber and release new video
item.description: • New video shows officer walk out of frame just before powerful blast • Officer: RV message changed and played a song by Petula Clark

item.title: Fauci predicts when general public will receive vaccine
item.description: • Fauci says he believes worst is still to come in the pandemic • NY health care provider may have fraudulently obtained vaccines, state says

item.title: A 7-year-old boy went back into a burning home to save his baby sister
item.description: A 7-year-old boy named Eli saved his baby sister's life when he jumped into her room through a window to rescue her from a fire that destroyed his family's home.

item.title: Two women and three girls were found dead in Arkansas on Christmas Day
item.description: A relative visiting family at Christmas made a gruesome discovery when they entered their relatives' Pope County, Arkansas, home to find two women and three girls dead.

item.title: Jim Acosta: I'm not the only White House reporter who got death threats
item.description: It's a been a whirlwind four years for reporters covering Donald Trump's presidency, a time marked by a never-ending campaign of attacks on the press.

item.title: 'Fascinating': Former FBI deputy director on what Nashville press conference revealed
item.description: Former FBI Deputy Director Andrew McCabe reacts to authorities identifying 63-year-old Anthony Quinn Warner as the Nashville bomber after matching his DNA to remains found at the scene of the explosion.

item.title: Seven killed in knife attack in northeast China
item.description: At least seven people were killed Sunday morning by a knife-wielding attacker in northeast China, according to state media.

item.title: Here's what happened when Democrats challenged Bush's win
Footage shows Russian police raiding home of activist
item.description: Police raided the home of Russian opposition activist Lyubov Sobol and took her in for questioning, according to a series of tweets from opposition leader Alexey Navalny and his team. CNN's Fred Pleitgen reports.

item.title: Uganda opposition candidate says his bodyguard was 'deliberately' run over
item.description: Ugandan presidential opposition candidate Bobi Wine said one of his bodyguards was run over and killed Sunday by a military police truck, while taking a journalist to the hospital.

item.title: Opinion: What's missing in Biden Covid plan
item.description: As we head into the next chapter of an ongoing pandemic — one in which a vaccine will hopefully let us see a light at the end of the tunnel — we must be careful not to ease up on the precautionary measures that will keep us safe while we wait for immunity.

item.title: Bitcoin is crashing -- upward. It soared above $28,000
item.description: Bitcoin is crashing -- upward. It just passed $28,000 and shows no signs of stopping.

item.title: CNN senior editor and wife remember 9-month-old daughter in touching essay
item.description: CNN's senior editor and founding member of KFile Andrew Kaczynski and his wife remember their 9-month-old daughter Francesca, who died after her battle with cancer, in an essay.

item.title: 'Wonder Woman 3' is coming soon, and Warner Bros. calls '1984' a hit
item.description: The box office numbers are in, and Warner Bros. says "Wonder Woman 1984" is a hit.

item.title: Get a first look at the Times Square New Year's Eve lights
item.description: Get a close up look at the Times Square 2021 lights as the new year approaches.

item.title: Hall of Fame pitcher Phil Niekro has died
item.description: Baseball Hall of Fame pitcher Phil Niekro has died at the age of 81 after a battle with cancer, the Atlanta Braves announced on Sunday.

item.title: This chase sequence changed Bond movies forever
item.description: Filmed in Switzerland's Urseren Valley, the famous Alpine scene in 1964's "Goldfinger" set a new benchmark for the 007 movie franchise.

item.title: Fake body bags placed on Alabama courthouse lawn in anti-Confederate protest
item.description: For months, a group of protesters in Alabama has been fighting for the removal of a Confederate flag and a Confederate monument that sit in front of the Marshall County Courthouse in Albertville.

item.title: Utah football star Ty Jordan dies at 19
item.description: University of Utah star freshman running back Ty Jordan has died at the age of 19, the school announced on Saturday.

item.title: If you want to travel next year, you may need a vaccine passport
item.description: Now that coronavirus vaccines are starting to roll out in the US and abroad, many people may be dreaming of the day when they can travel, shop and go to the movies again. But in order to do those activities, you may eventually need something in addition to the vaccine: a vaccine passport application.

item.title: Europe launches mass vaccination program as countries race to contain new variant
item.description: A pilot took to the skies above Germany using his flight path to draw a syringe, ahead of the launch of the Covid-19 vaccination campaign across Europe, according to data from FlightRadar24.

item.title: December is the deadliest month in the US since the pandemic began
item.description: • 1 in 1,000 Americans have died from Covid-19

item.title: Japan will ban entry to foreign nationals after Covid-19 variant detected in country
item.description: Japan will ban foreign nationals from entering the country from Monday through the end of January after several cases of the new Covid-19 variant were recorded in the country, the Japanese foreign ministry said in a statement on Saturday.

item.title: Photos from a strange year for travel
item.description: It's been a year like no other. As we began 2020, travelers had more freedom of movement than at any time in history. Air traffic had been rising for decades.

item.title: John Travolta shares video of his family's first Christmas since his wife's death
item.description: John Travolta shared a cheerful video of his children celebrating Christmas and wishing his followers a happy holiday.

item.title: Tom Brady lifts Buccaneers into playoffs with record-breaking performance
item.description: Tom Brady marked his 300th regular season game with a stellar performance to lift the Tampa Bay Buccaneers into the NFL playoffs for the first time since 2007 with a 47-7 rout of the Detroit Lions.

item.title: NHL owner buys Michael Jackson's Neverland Ranch
item.description: The property formerly known as Neverland Ranch, home to the late Michael Jackson, has been purchased by Pittsburgh Penguins co-owner Ron Burkle, Burkle's spokesman confirmed to CNN Saturday.

item.title: A 70-year-old employee known as 'Taco Bell Joe' got a $6,000 tip
item.description: A Taco Bell employee so loved by his community that he's known as "Taco Bell Joe" received a $6,095 tip raised by hundreds of his supporters.

item.title: Silke Sollfrank wants to encourage more women to take up parkour
item.description: Tired of the "rules" of gymnastics, Silke Sollfrank turned to a world of free running and body exploration. Sollfrank says parkour wasn't exactly the route her father had hoped she'd take. But she persisted and now, she wants more women to take up parkour.

item.title: Historical images of men in love from the 1850s to 1950s
item.description: Collectors Hugh Nini and Neal Treadwell have amassed almost 3,000 historical photos showing what appears to be same-sex couples. They have now published more than 300 of the images in the book "Loving: A Photographic History of Men in Love, 1850s-1950s."

item.title: These are the deadliest US jobs
item.description: Work-related deaths reached a 12-year high in 2019 at more than 5,300, according to new data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics.

item.title: This might be the most valuable Hot Wheels car
item.description: You can buy most Hot Wheels cars for about a dollar at Target, Wal-Mart or pretty much any local drugstore. But for Bruce Pascal, a nearly lifelong obsession with the tiny cars has turned into a collection of mind-boggling value.

item.title: Analysis: Brexit will leave the UK poorer
item.description: The United Kingdom and the European Union have agreed on a trade deal, closing the book on more than four years of uncertainty over how the country would conduct business with its biggest export market following Brexit.

item.title: We tested dozens of kitchen essentials in 2020. Here are the best ones worth buying
After-Christmas sales worth shopping this holiday weekend
The best WFH products to build your ultimate home office in 2021
Celebs swear by this $15 Amazon face mask
Don't let your FSA dollars expire: Here are some ways to spend 'em
The best standing desks you'll actually want to use at home
Ring in 2021 with these adorable New Year's nail art ideas
I used an iPhone 12 Pro for 2 months. Here are the pros and cons
Start getting rid of your debt in 2021 with these balance transfer credit cards
This $35 online piano course is surprisingly in-depth
The best coupons at Chewy
The winners of the post-Trump era
item.description: Each year, we ask a group of CNN Opinion contributors to make 10 predictions about some of the biggest political, cultural and sports moments to come.

item.title: Trump is destroying his own party on the way out the door
item.description: This holiday season, President Donald Trump has wreaked havoc on Congress, our democracy and our judicial system by pardoning political associates and convicted murderers. But Trump has saved a special kind of Grinch-like behavior for the two Republican Senate candidates in Georgia who are headed for runoff elections in January and for Senator Mitch McConnell, whose fate as majority leader depends on the GOP winning at least one of those races.

item.title: The Trump appointee Biden must dump on Day 1
item.description: Among the latest flurry of hair-raising Donald Trump appointees President-elect Joe Biden should replace as soon as possible, the name of Darren J. Beattie may not raise alarms quite like recently-installed Voice of America director Robert R. Reilly, author of controversial books like "Making Gay Okay: How Rationalizing Homosexual Behavior Is Changing Everything" and "The Closing of the Muslim Mind: How Intellectual Suicide Created the Modern Islamist Crisis." But Beattie's presence at a federally funded entity could undermine US democracy and pose nefarious consequences.

item.title: FBI team leader: How I know the Blackwater defendants didn't deserve a pardon from Trump
item.description: The President of the United States has the power to grant a pardon to anyone he believes deserves one. This is an incredible power when used for good. There are cases where the US justice system gets it wrong and cases where the defendants had served their time and were now doing good things. However, none of those fact patterns are present in President Donald Trump's pardon of four Blackwater security guards serving time for their involvement in the killing of 17 Iraqis in Baghdad on September 16, 2007.

item.title: The unforgivable thing about the Covid-19 response
item.description: The first case of Covid-19 in the United States was reported 11 months ago, on January 20, 2020. Since that time, more than 18 million Americans have been diagnosed and more than 329,000 have died.

item.title: Kasparov: Treat Russia like the rogue regime it is
item.description: In a series of events capable of stunning even veteran Russia watchers, Kremlin critic Alexey Navalny was nearly killed with a rare nerve agent before he recovered from a coma and went on to trick one of his apparent assassins into confessing to the details of the plot on tape.

item.title: Joe Biden bets on old allies to help him confront new crises
item.description: President-elect Joe Biden is leaning on familiar faces and old allies from his decades in public life as he builds an administration that will immediately confront a storm of extraordinary interlocking crises.

item.title: Analysis: Trump won the economic message battle
item.description: President Donald Trump has always liked to talk about how strong the economy was under his watch.

item.title: Georgia ballots to be treated as express mail
item.description: The US Postal Service has agreed to take extraordinary measures to deliver mailed ballots for Georgia's upcoming Senate runoff elections, including treating ballots as express mail, sweeping postal facilities for ballots and making special arrangements to ensure ballots reach the state election board's offices in a more timely manner.

item.title: New $600 stimulus checks in limbo
item.description: A second round of stimulus payments that was included in a coronavirus relief package passed by Congress Monday night is now at risk if President Donald Trump doesn't sign the bill.

item.title: Analysis: How Trump's presidency was always going to end
item.description: It was once said about a famous TV personality that when he left a job, he didn't burn bridges with his past employer, he napalmed them.

item.title: Analysis: Trump was playing a pardon long game
item.description: More than a year and a half ago, special counsel Robert Mueller had caught on to what President Donald Trump might do with his pardon power.

item.title: Less debt in 2021: Refinance your mortgage
5 cards charging 0% interest until 2022
Motley Fool's rare triple-buy alert
Queen Elizabeth had a rough 2020. But the pandemic gave her renewed relevance.
item.description: 2020 was a tumultuous year for most people, and that's no less true for Queen Elizabeth II.

item.title: China turns off the lights in 'Christmas town'
item.description: For months, factories in the city of Yiwu, known as China's "Christmas town," have been cranking out most of the tinsel, decorations and other festive ornaments now hanging on trees worldwide.

item.title: The major events that changed the world in 2020
item.description: 2020 has been an unforgettable year. We've witnessed world-changing, paradigm-shifting events, all under the cloud of the Covid-19 pandemic. CNN's Clarissa Ward looks back at the major international events of the year.

item.title: Analysis: 2020 derailed even Putin's plans
item.description: Russian President Vladimir Putin began 2020 with a surprise, sweeping his entire government aside on January 15 after unveiling a raft of constitutional reforms.
